interview_questions.question: What is an HTML element?
interview_questions.answer: An HTML element is usually consisting of a start tag and end tag, with the content inserted in between. Some elements are empty and have no enclosing content.

interview_questions.question: What is a void element?
interview_questions.answer:
A void element (or empty element) is an element that cannot have any child nodes (content). It does not requires a closing tag. Examples:

interview_questions.answer:
HTML tags are not case sensitive:

practice_problems.problem: Create a nested structure with a <div> containing a heading and a paragraph.
practice_problems.hint: Put h1 and p inside div tags.

real_world_use_cases.description: The browser converts your nested HTML elements into a DOM Tree (Document Object Model) which JavaScript can interact with.

exam_notes: Element = Start Tag + Content + End Tag
Empty elements (br, hr, img) do not have end tags
Tags are not case sensitive (but use lowercase)
Correct nesting is crucial (Finish what you started inner-most first)
summary:
HTML elements form the building blocks of web pages. Most elements have a start tag, content, and an end tag, but some 'empty' elements like
do not. Elements can be nested inside each other to create complex document structures.
